quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Energy Conservation
quiz.subtitle: Unit 3 Quiz 2 – Mechanical Energy and Heat Loss
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Mechanical Energy, Potential & Kinetic Energy, Heat Loss, Efficiency

questions.question: A 2 kg ball is dropped from a height of 15 m. Upon hitting the ground, it rebounds to a height of 9 m. How much energy is lost as heat/sound during the bounce? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Initial PE = mgh = 2 × 10 × 15 = 300 J. Final PE after bounce = 2 × 10 × 9 = 180 J. Energy lost as heat = 300 − 180 = 120 J.

questions.question: A 50 kg skier starts from rest at the top of a 40 m high hill and reaches the bottom at 25 m/s. How much mechanical energy was lost to friction/air resistance as heat? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Initial PE = mgh = 50 × 10 × 40 = 20000 J. Final KE = ½ × 50 × (25)² = 6250 J. Energy lost as heat = 20000 − 6250 = 13750 J.

questions.question: A bullet of mass 0.02 kg traveling at 400 m/s penetrates a wall and exits at 200 m/s. All lost kinetic energy becomes heat. How much heat is generated?
A 1200 kg car moving at 30 m/s brakes to a complete stop. If all kinetic energy is converted to heat in the brakes, how much heat is produced?
questions.explanation: KE = ½ × 1200 × 30² = 540,000 J = 540 kJ. All becomes heat.

questions.question: A 0.5 kg block slides down a rough incline, losing 12 J of mechanical energy due to friction. If it started with 50 J of total mechanical energy at the top, what percentage of initial energy became heat?
questions.explanation: Heat loss = 12 J out of 50 J initial. Percentage = (12 / 50) × 100 = 24%.

questions.question: A simple pendulum of mass 0.2 kg is pulled aside so its bob is 0.8 m above its lowest point. It is released, and at the lowest point its speed is 3 m/s instead of the ideal 4 m/s. How much energy was lost as heat due to air resistance? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Initial PE = mgh = 0.2 × 10 × 0.8 = 1.6 J. Actual KE = 0.5 × 0.2 × 3² = 0.9 J. Heat loss = 1.6 − 0.9 = 0.7 J.

questions.question: A 10 kg crate is pushed across a horizontal floor with a force of 40 N over 5 m. If the crate moves at constant speed, how much work is done against friction, and what becomes of that energy?
questions.explanation: At constant speed, friction = 40 N opposite motion. Work against friction = 40 × 5 = 200 J. This energy is dissipated as heat.

questions.question: A motor lifts a 100 kg load at constant speed through 10 m. The motor’s electrical energy input is 12,000 J. How much energy is lost as heat in the motor and cables? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Useful work = mgh = 100 × 10 × 10 = 10,000 J. Energy input = 12,000 J. Heat loss = 12,000 − 10,000 = 2,000 J.

questions.question: A 0.1 kg metal sphere is dropped into a tall oil-filled tube. It falls at constant terminal velocity. What happens to the gravitational potential energy it loses?
options: It becomes heat in the oil
It is stored as elastic energy
questions.explanation: At constant velocity, ΔKE = 0, so all lost PE is dissipated as heat via fluid friction in the oil.

questions.question: A cyclist generates 300 W of mechanical power while riding on flat ground at constant speed. If her body is 20% efficient at converting chemical energy to mechanical work, at what rate is heat generated in her body?
questions.explanation: Efficiency = mechanical output / total input → 0.20 = 300 / Input → Input = 1500 W. Heat rate = Input − Output = 1500 − 300 = 1200 W.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent understanding of energy conservation and heat loss.
scoreMessages.70: Good grasp; review energy loss in non-conservative systems.
scoreMessages.50: Fair; practice relating work, energy changes, and heat dissipation.
scoreMessages.0: Review mechanical energy concepts and energy conversion to heat.
